turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about History of radio disc jockeys.
turn.1: What are the main aspects of being a radio DJ?
turn.2: With exceptions such as Halloween Martin's work in 1929 at WBBM in Chicago, the radio DJ profession in the U.S. was historically male-dominated.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: However beginning in the Top 40 era, female disc jockeys became more common.
turn.5: Did they have any specific roles?
turn.6: Judy Dibble on WDGY in Minneapolis started as "sidekick" to a male DJ in the mid 1960s and later went on to host her own DJ show.
turn.8: Alison Steele began her career at WNEW-FM in the late 1960s.
turn.10: Responding to an ad for female disk jockeys, Steele auditioned with 800 other women and was chosen with three others to launch an "all woman" format.
turn.11: What happened with the "all woman" format?
turn.12: When WNEW abandoned this format in 1967 after an 18‐month trial, Steele was the only one asked to stay on.
